ygData.messageBody:
>I've subscribed to this list to learn more about smithing not to collude with
>all the other smiths in the game in an attempt to "profit" from customers by
>setting arbitrary prices. I myself am from the United States where our
>economy is capitalism. We reject the ideas of collusion and oligopolies
>because we believe that the one who builds the better mousetrap will win
out.
>EQ is showing us that as we saturate it with more and more smiths the prices
>will be driven down due to increased supply. I read an email earlier about
>someone who diversified himself and mastered other skills to sell items in
>addition to his armor. I apologize that I forgot your name, and I've
already
>deleted the email, but you are the one who will succeed because you're
>accepting the price war of armor and offering more to the customer. If you
>don't learn to offer more to the customer you will be priced out of the
>market.

Ok there is something your missing here: fair play.

Nobody is "colluding" or trying to monopolize any industry here. REMEMBER
that EQ's ECONOMY IS BROKEN. Therefore the standard rules of economy DO NOT
APPLY.

What we are trying to do is make smithing profitable so that people are
willing to do it. When the game first started, EVERYONE did smithing. When
people started selling at 1gp above cost, 90% of those people quit. Now you
cannot find very many smiths at all (in fact, in the last week of play I
have found 2 stretching from Qeynos, to Freeport, to Kelethin - on E'ci).

If we can settle on a base price (which the economy SHOULD be doing for
us, but is NOT doing), then we can make it profitable enough to do some
smithing. If not...well then you will still have the majority of people not
smithing, and a few who DO smith and corner the market.

You choose.
